Headlines: Pakistan braces for top court verdict on Panamagate today
Descriptions: ISLAMABAD/KARACHI:A looming Supreme Court decision that could disqualify Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif over corruption allegations had the country on edge on Wednesday, as a drawn-out investigation related to the “Panama Papers” leaks neared a conclusion.
Articles: Islamabad/Karachi, April 19A looming Supreme Court decision that could disqualify Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif over corruption allegations had the country on edge on Wednesday, as a drawn-out investigation related to the “Panama Papers” leaks neared a conclusion.Disqualifying Sharif would leave his party in power, but it would cause intense turmoil at a time when Pakistan is experiencing modest growth and improved security after years of violence, and the civilian government and powerful military have appeared to come to uneasy terms.Sharif has denied any wrongdoing, but the Supreme Court agreed to investigate his family’s offshore wealth late last year after opposition leader Imran Khan threatened street protests.The SC could take a range of steps. It could clear the prime minister, or order a further judicial commission of inquiry or even declare him ineligible to hold office, as it did in 2012 with then-Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gilani over a contempt of court case.Naeem ul Haque, a spokesman for Khan’s Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) said he expected a verdict against Sharif, but he made clear the opposition would not launch a new street movement if they were disappointed.(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({ });In 2014, Khan led a months-long protest that paralysed the government quarter in the capital, Islamabad, after rejecting Sharif’s decisive election win a year earlier.The case stems from documents leaked from the Panama-based Mossack Fonseca law firm appeared to show that Sharif’s daughter and two sons owned offshore holding companies registered in the British Virgin Islands and used them to buy properties in London.Sharif told Parliament last year that his family wealth was acquired legally in the decades before he entered politics and that no money was siphoned off-shore. — ReutersHistory’s biggest data leak The Panama Papers are an unprecedented leak of 11.5m files from the database of the world’s fourth biggest offshore law firm, Mossack Fonseca. The records were obtained from an anonymous source by the German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung, which shared them with the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ). The ICIJ then shared them with a large network of international partners, including the Guardian and the BBC.What do they reveal?The documents show the myriad ways in which the rich can exploit secretive offshore tax regimes. Twelve national leaders are among 143 politicians, their families and close associates from around the world known to have been using offshore tax havens.A $2bn trail leads all the way to Vladimir Putin. Among national leaders with offshore wealth are Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan’s PM; Ayad Allawi, ex-interim prime minister and former vice-president of Iraq; Petro Poroshenko, president of Ukraine; Alaa Mubarak, son of Egypt’s former president; and the prime minister of Iceland, Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson.What is Mossack Fonseca?It is a Panama-based law firm whose services include incorporating companies in offshore jurisdictions such as the British Virgin Islands. It administers offshore firms for a yearly fee. Other services include wealth management.Where is it based?The firm is Panamanian but runs a worldwide operation. Its website boasts of a global network with 600 people working in 42 countries. It has franchises around the world, where separately owned affiliates sign up new customers and have exclusive rights to use its brand. Mossack Fonseca operates in tax havens including Switzerland, Cyprus and the British Virgin Islands, and in the British crown dependencies Guernsey, Jersey and the Isle of Man.

Headlines: One-appmanship!
Descriptions: What would you rather choose—chase a woman or a man, face the fear of rejection and impending ridicule or secretly type into the screen in complete privacy? Well, finding love online comes handy in a society where dating still cuts little ice.
Articles: MonaWhat would you rather choose—chase a woman or a man, face the fear of rejection and impending ridicule or secretly type into the screen in complete privacy? Well, finding love online comes handy in a society where dating still cuts little ice.Now, in person someone might not be able to utter two coherent sentences to a potential date but online, for instance, you can talk to Julia Roberts and she may actually respond!High probability of finding a date purely due to numbers, less trauma of rejection and no audience to revel in your failure, make virtual dating a haven for lonely or not-so-lonely souls.Talk of online dating, Tinder it is today. Right swipe for a like, left for a no, this one app has changed how people pursue their love interests and how. Touted to be the best platform to meet new people, it is trending big time and if you thought it’s for the young ones, please, its reach has spread far and wide.Aimed at an age group of 18 to 55+, you will find men and women using the same platform to fulfil varied purposes. Gurpreet, 20, made some new friends and met few of them too. A body buff that he is, his pictures kept attracting attention (super likes). But this Panjab University law student had to tune off from the app for it was too distracting, “There is constant stream of new people matching you, it is difficult to keep up.”(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({ });However, hooking up was what in Ankush Grewal’s (a freelance app developer) mind and that’s what he got after a very time consuming, tedious exercise. “I like Tinder for it lets me be. I am married. I had a real date with a woman from another city, and no, I don’t feel guilty.”For Manish Singla, a project manager with a tech firm, online dating works wonders as his job takes him to different places, meetings done, an evening free and here are options galore. “It’s always great to find new people and spent some time online or if lucky offline too, and Tinder truly assists in that.”However, the app works better in the metros than small cities like Chandigarh. For Nitin, a lawyer, it’s been frustrating exercise for all he could see was his own peer group. But things changed as he changed his location. “I was in Mumbai and it’s like an unending line of new faces. I did get a real date, but here in Chandigarh, I would rather hang out with my own friends.”For Prakriti, master psychology student, this app is lame for there are too many fake profiles. “Here, you just see the picture and swipe. Sadly in the times of photo editing softwares, you really can’t tell,” she rues.An ego booster is how Nitisha, a 29-year old human resource manager, labels online dating apps. “With the amount of attention I get here makes up for the long work hours that I am made put in.” However, she says “Please don’t fall for taglines like ‘Not here for hook-ups’.mona@tribunemail.comPlay by your rulesTinder is place to meet new people. It’s fresh, convenient and happening. With time one evolves. Yes, boys would chase girls and vice versa in campuses and now they do the same in virtual space. At least this gives one a chance to familiarise with new people before you give them an entry in real life. Now, conservatives call Tinder names, level accusations that it encourages adultery. One, it’s an open platform, nobody is pushing you into it. You go if you like it, and play as per your principles. Friends, dates, partying, one night stands – you weigh, measure and take your call. Now, isn’t adultery as old as human race? If you want to do something, you would do it with or without Tinder.  I fail to understand the hue and cry made about it.—Vaibhav, chief officer, merchant navy No real action I feel people who go online dating do not have friends in real life. Since Tinder is trending big time, someone downloaded the app on my phone in the gym. No, it doesn’t work for me. I believe in making friends, not adding them. The platform brings you face to face with many, you like some, chat for a day or two and move on. Probably it works for younger generation which is looking for distractions, I am not. Married men looking for hook ups, married women looking for sex with anonymous people; it is a strange place to be in. No quality, only the numbers. May work for ‘quickly move on’ types. I am the stable sort, so I deleted it after finding it no use in a few days. —Nikhil Kumar, marketing head, beverage brandNo hiding from this oneThere are issues with Tinder, like you can't hide or delete chats. Once you delete your account, your connects vanish with it too if you have not already exchanged phone numbers or Skype accounts. Doesn't matter if connects here don't last long, there are reasons - families finding out and leading to deletion of accounts but then there are new matches to be found. - Ankit Sood, bankerA crazy worldTried Tinder and woe betide, I was approached by a pimp offering staggering Rs 35000 with a 50 per cent cut a night. All kind of people trawl the virtual world, beware! - Maninder Singh, entrepreneurWin someOnline dating is like a lottery with free tickets. Who would want to miss a free chance? However miniscule the odds. - Saurabh Sharma, pilotGet the hang of itTempted? Here is how it works...download the app, log in with your Facebook account. See the options, left swipe on profile you are not interested in, right for the one you are. If the person you have liked has liked you too, it’s a match. You can converse on the app. And, if you really like someone, you can super like. When they browse your profile they get a notification.Trying online dating, here are few terms for you:Sapiosexual: One who finds intelligence the most sexually attractive feature.Benching: To put the other party on hold. Not replying for days, big gestures not translating in real. Ghosting: To cease all communication in hope that other person can take the hint, which is back off. Get charmedHappn: Looking for something more real, Happn is your app. It puts you in touch with people you have crossed paths with. Like most dating apps, you can like someone anonymously, here it is called ‘charm’. Get ready to see loads of neighbours here.(Some of the names have been changed on request)
